verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: This marks a new oracle, emphasizing the prophetic authority and divine origin of Ezekiel’s words.

verses.text: Son of man, speak to the children of your people and say to them, ‘Suppose I bring a sword upon a land, and the people of that land choose one of their men and set him as their watchman;
verses.comment: The role of the watchman symbolizes prophetic vigilance and accountability.

verses.text: and when he sees the sword coming upon the land, he blows the trumpet and warns the people.
verses.comment: Here, sounding the trumpet represents bringing warning and calling to repentance.

verses.text: Then, whoever hears the sound of the trumpet but does not heed the warning, and the sword comes and takes him away, his blood will be on his own head.
verses.comment: Personal responsibility for rejecting the warning is emphasized (see Ezek. 18’s theme of individual accountability).

verses.text: He heard the sound of the trumpet but did not take warning; his blood will be upon himself. If he had heeded the warning, he would have saved his life.
verses.comment: Moral responsibility rests upon the individual to respond to God’s call.

verses.text: But if the watchman sees the sword coming and does not blow the trumpet, so that the people are not warned, and the sword comes and takes away any of them, that person's blood will be required at the watchman's hand.
verses.comment: The prophet is held accountable for failing to warn others—a parallel to spiritual leaders’ responsibilities in the New Testament.

verses.text: Now, as for you, son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel. So you shall hear the word from My mouth and give them warning from Me.
verses.comment: Ezekiel’s mission is reaffirmed, mirroring the prophetic authority bestowed by God.

verses.text: If I say to the wicked, ‘O wicked man, you will surely die,’ and you do not speak to warn the wicked from his way, that wicked person shall die in his iniquity, but his blood I will require at your hand.
verses.comment: Prophets bear a real responsibility before God—note implication for all spiritual leaders.

verses.text: But if you warn the wicked to turn from his way, and he does not turn from it, he shall die in his iniquity, but you have delivered your soul.
verses.comment: Just as in Ezek. 3:19, the prophet is cleared of guilt if he fulfills his duty.

verses.text: As for you, son of man, say to the house of Israel, ‘This is what you are saying: Surely our transgressions and our sins are upon us, and we waste away because of them. How then can we live?’
verses.comment: The people’s sense of hopelessness sets the stage for God’s message of mercy and the possibility of restoration.

verses.text: Say to them: ‘As surely as I live,’ declares the Lord GOD, ‘I take no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but rather that the wicked turn from his way and live. Turn back, turn back from your evil ways! Why should you die, O house of Israel?’
verses.comment: This verse highlights God’s mercy and desire for repentance, resonating with New Testament themes of forgiveness and reconciliation (cf. Luke 15:7).

verses.text: Therefore, son of man, say to your people: The righteousness of the righteous will not deliver him if he transgresses; and as for the wickedness of the wicked, he shall not fall by it when he turns from his wickedness. Nor shall the righteous be able to live by their righteousness if they sin.
verses.comment: A teaching on ongoing faithfulness—not once saved, always saved; ongoing conversion and perseverance are crucial (see Phil. 2:12).

verses.text: When I say to the righteous that he shall surely live, but he trusts in his own righteousness and commits unrighteousness, none of his righteous deeds shall be remembered; but in the unrighteousness that he has done, he shall die.
verses.comment: Warnings against self-reliance; the spiritual life must be preserved through grace and ongoing conversion.

verses.text: Again, when I say to the wicked, ‘You shall surely die,’ yet he turns from his sin and does what is lawful and right,
verses.comment: Repentance brings renewal and forgiveness—a fundamental pattern throughout Scripture (cf. Acts 2:38).

verses.text: if the wicked restores the pledge, gives back what he has stolen, walks in the statutes of life, and commits no injustice, he shall surely live; he shall not die.
verses.comment: True repentance involves restitution and transformed living (see Zacchaeus in Luke 19:8).

verses.text: None of the sins he has committed shall be remembered against him. He has done what is lawful and right; he shall surely live.
verses.comment: God’s forgiveness is complete for the penitent—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s sacrifice, which brings true reconciliation.

verses.text: Yet your people say, ‘The way of the Lord is not just.’ But it is their own way that is not just.
verses.comment: Human tendency to question God’s justice is countered: true justice is found in God’s ways, not in human opinion.

verses.text: When the righteous turns away from his righteousness and practices iniquity, he shall die for it.
verses.comment: Perseverance is needed in righteousness—a consistent biblical theme (see Matt. 24:13).

verses.text: But when the wicked turns from his wickedness and does what is lawful and right, he shall live because of it.
verses.comment: God’s mercy invites continual conversion—a principle manifest in Christ’s teaching and in the sacraments of reconciliation.

verses.text: Yet you say, ‘The way of the Lord is not just.’ O house of Israel, I will judge each of you according to his ways.
verses.comment: This foreshadows New Testament teachings on personal judgment and God’s perfect justice.

verses.text: In the twelfth year of our exile, in the tenth month, on the fifth day of the month, a man who had escaped from Jerusalem came to me and said, ‘The city has been struck down.’
verses.comment: This is the historical fulfillment of Ezekiel’s earlier prophecies—a tangible sign of God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: Now the hand of the LORD had been upon me in the evening before the fugitive arrived, and He had opened my mouth. My mouth was opened and I was no longer mute when the man came to me in the morning.
verses.comment: Ezekiel’s speech is released at the fulfillment of prophecy, signifying restored prophetic authority.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: A second divine address introduces a new prophetic message within the chapter.

verses.text: Son of man, the inhabitants of these desolate ruins in the land of Israel are saying, ‘Abraham was only one, yet he possessed the land; but we are many, the land has surely been given to us to possess.’
verses.comment: The people rely on ancestry and numbers, misunderstanding the covenant’s requirements (see Gen. 13:15).

verses.text: Therefore say to them, ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: You eat meat with blood, you lift up your eyes to your idols, and shed blood. Should you then possess the land?’
verses.comment: Violation of God’s law—especially concerning idolatry and dietary law—invalidates their claim to the covenant blessing.

verses.text: You stand upon your sword, you commit abominations, and each of you defiles his neighbor's wife. Should you then possess the land?
verses.comment: Immorality and violence further show how the people’s actions contradict God’s covenant demands.

verses.text: Say this to them: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: As surely as I live, those who are in the ruins shall fall by the sword, and whoever is out in the field I will give to the beasts to be devoured, and those in the fortresses and caves shall die by pestilence.
verses.comment: Comprehensive judgment is declared against unrepentant Israel, matching previous warnings and reflecting divine justice.

verses.text: I will make the land a desolation and a waste, and its proud strength will cease; the mountains of Israel will be so desolate that no one will pass through.
verses.comment: This verse recalls earlier prophecies of desolation as a consequence of sin.

verses.text: Then they will know that I am the LORD, when I have made the land a desolation and a waste because of all their abominations which they have committed.
verses.comment: The recognition of God’s sovereignty comes both through judgment and later restoration—an important biblical pattern.

verses.text: As for you, son of man, the children of your people are talking about you beside the walls and at the doors of the houses; they speak one to another, each to his brother, saying, ‘Come, and hear what the word is that comes from the LORD.’
verses.comment: People discuss Ezekiel’s message, showing its public impact and the draw of prophetic teaching.

verses.text: They come to you as people come, and they sit before you as My people, and they hear your words, but they do not do them; for with their mouth they show much love, but their heart goes after their gain.
verses.comment: Hearing without obeying is condemned—true faith entails both hearing and doing (see Matt. 7:21-23).

verses.text: Indeed, to them you are like one who sings love songs with a beautiful voice and plays skillfully; they hear your words but do not act on them.
verses.comment: Faith is shown by action, not mere appreciation or lip service—a key for spiritual growth and authentic discipleship.

verses.text: But when it comes to pass—behold, it will come—then they will know that a prophet has been among them.
verses.comment: Prophecy is validated by fulfillment; Jesus applies this principle to Himself, confirming His prophetic and divine authority (see John 13:19).
